subject: RE: [junit] Testability
msgSnippet: ... I can t toot my own horn too loudly on this because Boris Beizer had a similar insight in his book Software Testing Techniques, but we arrived at it
messageBody:
> -----Original Message-----
> From: Eric Armstrong [mailto:eric.armstrong@...]
>
> This is really profound. I've implemented fsm's before, but never
> characterized a "testable app" as one that effectively *is* one.

I can't toot my own horn too loudly on this because Boris Beizer had a
similar insight in his book 'Software Testing Techniques,' but we arrived at
it independently. Finding his discussion of testability in relation to
FSM's gave me confidence to say what I thought.

I think the FSM is a fruitful source of ideas about what testability
entails. I also think it well-describes the end product of a religiously
developed TDD application. That is, everything is clean, tight, purposeful
and geared toward producing the right output at every step of the way.

Since I've begun thinking about this I've scoured all the books I have and
could find at the local Borders and Barnes & Noble, and have mostly come
across pretty shallow treatments of testability in software testing and
engineering books. Beizer's is by far the best example, where he discusses
testability in several places with specifics. Of course Kent Beck's and
Robert Martin's books have a lot of insights and relevance for testability,
but the word itself is almost never, if ever, used or analyzed.

I was disappointed to see the new book 'Testing Extreme Programming' had a
couple of pages of fluff dedicated to the topic of "testability."

> Note:
> Here, I find that I need an example to follow the discussion.

I am now working on some examples. I need them myself to better generalize
what the real principles are and see how apt this FSM idea is.

Scott S.
